response.content:
Hi,

Docker's documentation doesn't talk about a lot of what's covered in this course, such as setting up a server and deploying your app to production step by step.

You could go read documentation from 10 different technologies and roll your own set up, but doing so will take a lot more time and you would be missing out on pre-made working scripts and a bunch of insights gained from real world experience.

results.content:
Hi Nick,

I'm on Section 5, #26.   I'm enjoying the course and finding it to be very informative thus far.

2 Requests for the future:
1) Could you make the font in the terminal and sublime editor larger?  On smaller screens it's hard to read, or you end up doing a lot of zooming in/out and pausing the video which can be a distraction when trying to learn.
2) Could you enable word wrap in sublime (under the view menu)?  I found myself having to pause and rewind the video multiple times to see text that was past the right edge of the editor window.

Thanks for a great quality course!

results.content:
The "Docker for DevOps" course is a very valuable resource -- worth far more than the price of admission. Nick Janetakis is very detailed in the lectures and provides many PDF downloads of notes and scripts.

As a front-end developer for many years, I have found the server operations and setup to be very intimidating. Docker and other tools have made the process much more accessible. Nick Janetakis' "Docker for DevOps" course goes a step further, and makes these tools accessible.

Note:
I would suggest that there are some prerequisites for the course.  Some experience with using the terminal/command line would be extremely helpful. I did find that my previous limited experience in developing Flask apps helped me to follow the course better, as it provided context and familiarity.

results.content:
Hands-down one of the best tutorials/courses I've ever completed in any subject.

This tutorial is perfect for anyone who's developed web apps and is looking to graduate to more professional deployment schemes. If you've ever worked with AWS or similar, you know there's a significant barrier to getting a 'real' server running -- and keeping it running -- with minimal headache. This course covers everything from automating deployments to setting firewalls. Startups who can't afford to hire a dedicated DevOps, this is the tutorial you've been looking for!

Nick is clear, understandable, draws *fantastic* diagrams, and his steps are easy to follow. I'm confident I'm going to be able to extend what I've learned from this course onto other platforms and integrate other services.

response.content:
Hi,

In order to deploy a web app to production, it involves a lot of moving parts. There's a lot more to it than just learning Docker on its own. That's why all of those other topics are covered in detail. I wanted people to be able to take this course with no prior knowledge about app deployment and walk away with hosting their app securely on a server. Docker is 1 of many tools we learn in this course.

response.content:
Hi,

If I made it downloadable you would still need to know how to configure the VM, such as using a proper amount of resources for your system, setting up shared folders and so on.

It really wouldn't have saved much time to use a pre-baked image. Also, a lot of students have really enjoyed the extra VM knowledge. It's like you're getting a mini-course on VMs as a bonus (one of my student's words).

Also, setting up your environment is only a tiny fraction of the course. Don't worry, you'll get into Docker and the rest of the course in no time.

results.content: Most of the course is not actually about Docker. If I wanted to learn systemd, I would read the documentation for systemd. If I wanted to do bash scripting, I'd do bash scripting. If I wanted an advertisement for DigitalOcean, I would read their marketing material.

response.content:
Hi Joseph,

I'm sorry you feel that way.

Quite a bit of material covers using Docker (in the context of developing 2 different web applications) where Docker and Docker Compose are explained in those sections.

Then, we spend quite some time going over some of the technologies you mentioned (plus a lot more).

Deploying a web application to production in a reasonable way requires learning about a lot of different things.

For example, you need to rent a server somewhere, and DigitalOcean is well known for being one of the best cloud providers around when balancing price and simplicity, so that's why I chose and personally use them.

I spent 2 minutes to include my thought process on why I chose them on video because I think it's an important skill to have as a developer. You should be able to evaluate the tools you use.

bash scripts, systemd, nginx, SSL certificates and domain name are all necessary to learn about too. It's the full spectrum that takes you from development to production (thus the course name!).

Often times the "why" is just as important as the "how", and that's what you get with this course too. I explain my thought process on why we're doing everything, and then show you how to do it.

Actually, this course shifted from writing docker files to how to deploy at staging & production. Also Nick had a pre compiled deploy script with which he does all the staging & production magic. I expected that at the end of the course I would be able to write a Dockerfile from scratch but I am not able to write one from scratch instead i spent my most of the time in setting up the system for being in sync with nick tutorials. Dont recommend to those who are just wishing to learn docker. I recommend them to rather use docker docs which i found out later as the best resource. But yeah if someone wants to get to the very core of deployment & production then this is the best resource ever which walks you through the entire steps with broad details.
This is my honest review & i am not here to impress someone.
Thank You! Best of Luck!

results.content:
Learning requires effort. So will this course. No course is perfect. As neither is this.

However, I really enjoyed it. You will learn the fundamentals of Docker and, at the same time, you will get an environment comprising various tools that will let you deploy to staging and production servers. This environment really works, allowing you to customize it further as you may wish, and letting you do real worker when you're ready. This is really great.

As various tools are used (ssh, systemd, git, docker, postgresql, redis, flask, nginx), you should expect spending some time if you aren't acquainted to some of these technologies, as I wasn't, although the author does describe some of them as much as required to make all work.
I would recommend getting some good cheat sheets on git, docker, ..., and following the course closely to get things working first. Later you may gradually change what you want or need, as I found troubleshooting things difficult in docker containers . You may find that "docker logs <container>" will be your friend. That git commit --allow-empty -m "To force push" may be helpful if you need to push things again (new server, or when images are deleted). And, don't forget to "seed" postgresql database when is first used ..., or you may spend some hours trying to debug what is not wrong.

Regarding support, I had a few issues - mainly because I made some changes that caused errors - used Q & A, and was amazed when author replied in a few minutes.

Many thanks to the author.

results.content:
The good reviews are from people that just watched the videos without actually trying out the code. 

The bad reviews complain about not covering the more DevOps topics of security,  industry best practices, etc.

There's something even more fundamentally broken here, that neither group has realized.

Newsflash: The demos are completely and utterly broken. 

If you actually sit down and type out what he types => DOESN'T WORK. Too many mistakes and project structuring errors. I wasted 3 hours alone on this.

If you give up and use his zipped source files => DOESN'T WORK. His code is broken, just so broken.

I'm 8 hours into a supposedly 7.5 hour course, yet unable to get the first flask demo working. 

Just avoid this disorganized cesspool of an amateur train wreck.

response.content:
Hi Chris,

There's only 1 bad review out of 4,000+ students that mentions a lack of security and honestly, his review is inaccurate. The course goes over setting up a firewall, locking down SSH and configuring A+ SSL. These are all industry standard security best practices. I don't know how he missed them considering he said he finished the course.

Also out of 4,000+ students and hundreds of messages of feedback I can safely say that the code does work. Hundreds of students have proven they went through the material successfully, and it's only "hundreds" because those are only the vocal minority of students who decided to give feedback.

I've never seen you post an issue in the course's forums. I'm more than willing to help you if you post the details of your problems.

As for it being a "disorganized cesspool of an amateur train wreck", I'm sorry you feel that way. You're the first person who said things were disorganized. In fact, there's plenty of positive reviews where people said the course was very well put together and flowed nicely.

I'd love to hear your feedback as to why you think that way. Send me a PM if you want.

A lot of general info, but nothing special or deep. 
no deep info about security, links between containers etc. 
But lots of info about flask/rails, digitalocean... don't know what for. 

too little info about management(rancher/swarm/kubernetes)

PS review is written after completing course and obtaining certification.

response.content:
Hi,

There are lectures that deal with linking containers in detail. It's all in the Flask/Rails sections where we setup multiple containers to talk to each other.

There's also dedicated sections on security, such as configuring firewalls, locking down SSH and setting up A+ SSL. Did you skip all of those lectures?

The sections on Flask/Rails show you how you could "Dockerize" a web application. This handles the "development" side of things. Without this, you would have no idea how to use Docker in development.

There's a section on DigitalOcean because that's the cloud host we use to deploy the application to production. This course is meant to take you from nothing all the way to a hosted application in production on a custom domain.

results.content:
The instructor begins this video series by explaining that his initial attempts to learn deployment were frustrating because he read tutorials which told him to type in a bunch of commands -- but he had no understanding of why those commands were necessary.

He then states that Docker changes everything and we can learn from his mistakes.  
At this point, I thought I purchased the perfect video series to learn Docker.  Boy was I wrong.

What followed was several hours of him telling me to enter commands and giving me very poor explanation as to what those commands do.  He might give a broad overview of why the command --- but he won't explain why I'm the command is being decorated with various flags and options.

Furthermore, the videos are out of date and needlessly complex.  Docker now supports OSX and Windows out of the box.  This means less fussing with virtual machines.  None of that is mentioned here.

Worst of all, don't even attempt to follow along.  One video will end and the next video will begin and he'll surprise you by revealing he has written a ton of code between cuts.  He'll walk you through what he's done, but that's a poor way to learn.  The best courses allow you to work side-by-side with the instructor.  

Save your money and look for alternate resources.

response.content:
Hi,

Sorry you feel that way about the course. I just want to step in and clarify a few things that are slightly inaccurate with your review.

You say that I don't mention running Docker on OSX or Windows with the out of the box solution that exists today but I do. I added that video months ago when Docker Toolbox was made available.

There's plenty of students who are using Docker Toolbox (as per my video instructions) with great success.

There's also an additional bonus lecture that goes over upgrading everything to the latest Docker Compose syntax and Docker 1.10 (which is compatible with 1.12 as 1.12 for the most part only adds Swarm features). So the end result of what you learn in this course today is fully up to date, even today.

As for following along, sure you can. As you've noticed this course covers a lot of ground. In the last third of the course we build up a bash script together that gains complexity as it grows in size.

Instead of typing out a 400 line bash script character by character, I introduce a few new functions in each section while explaining each new piece of the script in that section. This allows you to see how the script changes, without having to sit there for 5 hours typing out the syntax of a bash script 1 character at a time (trust me, this would have been super annoying).

I'm curious how you would have presented the material in a better way so that I can further improve my course. So far most everyone else loved this teaching style, but it can always be improved upon.

response.content:
Ah I see what you mean. I'm not sure I would classify this as being out of sync. It's just how I presented some lectures.

For example, in the case you mentioned, I said the word before typing it out, rather than spelling out each letter in the word. This makes it sound like I'm typing after the word is spoken, but that's really just entering in what I said about 500ms after saying it.

To me, out of sync would be hearing audio that no longer matches what you see on screen. To my knowledge this never happens in the course. For example if you goto 7:50 where I say "space", you can see the space on the screen happen within 150ms which IMO falls into the category of still in sync.

I do appreciate the feedback tho, in future revisions I will make a note to spell out each command letter by letter so it feels more synced.

results.content:
I knew absolutely nothing about docker and now I think I can roll out a server with docker containers.

I really liked the approach to run a web app with many services (Postgres and redis), allowing us to play with a multi service environment. The focus on how to prepare a staging and production environment is a win.

As a bonus, you learn how to really automate deploy using git hooks.

I'd recommend this course to everyone interested in learning docker.

results.content: One of the best Docker courses on Udemy right now (I actually went through a few). It contains a good balance of theory and practical materials. While this is a course about Docker, it touches a lot on other useful concepts used by DevOps, such as lightweight automatic provisioning of servers, git hooks, etc. which I found really useful. The instructor also responds to queries really quickly. A possible downside is that it lacks the coverage of more advanced/modern Docker features, but those could well be made into another course altogether. Overall a 5-star course that any new DevOps should take!

The course has a perfect balance between theory (just enough to have a basic understanding and to go read wiki if interested/necessary) and practical material. The host is very helpful and friendly, answering very fast to any comments. Thank you, Nick! : )

The videos were all recorded at 1080p. Udemy is notorious for playing back videos at a much lower resolution. Also their non-computer video players are pretty bad (such as ipads, etc.).

I recommend you play back the videos at full screen and make sure they are set to 1080p. I have watched the content on multiple machines and had no issues reading the font. For some reason the smallness is only a concern for a small percentage of students.

I did boost up font sizes in my newer courses to better protect my content from being distorted by Udemy's platform. Thanks for the feedback.

So just to be clear, you're rating the course less than a 1 because of only the font size?

Perhaps I misunderstood the technology. I assumed by using docker server configuration would be easier.

The last 3 chapters have not included much beyond server configuration, it does not seem simpler than standard server configuration.

response.content:
Hi,

You still need to write config files to use them within Docker. For example, nginx runs in a Docker container, but we still need to provide an nginx config file.

As for things like firewall settings, those happen outside of Docker because they need to be ran on the host itself.

response.content:
Hi,

I'm sorry you feel that way. Configuring the application is only a small fraction of the entire course and you could skip those lectures if you're not interested.

The reason they are included is so that you can see how 2 different web frameworks can be configured to use Docker. This way you'll have some material to work off of to Dockerize your own web framework's code.

If I didn't teach you how to Dockerize a web application then you wouldn't be able to develop your application. This is explained in the introduction video and the course's title does include "from development to production". It's meant to provide you all the tools you need to get going with Docker to develop and deploy a web app to production.

results.content: Not a fan.  Most of the course is about setting up a VM environment, setting up OS-specific settings, python/ruby app specific settings, etc.  Aside from the first few sections, there was very little discussion about Docker.  The "quiz" questions and explanations are a joke.  I mean, if you're not going to take it seriously then don't have any!  I'm not impressed and I honestly can't recommend this course at all.

response.content:
Hi John,

Sorry you feel that way. There's only 1 lecture about setting up a VM in development. It's also optional because a second way of installing everything without a dedicated VM is given.

As for Python/Ruby app specific settings. For starters the entire Rails section is optional, you don't even have to watch a single lecture if you don't want to. The idea behind these sections are to give you multiple examples of how to Dockerize both a Flask and Rails app.

The course is meant to take you from beginning to end, and that starts with having to know how to Dockerize your app in development and also set up your development environment.

There's a lot of moving parts and technologies to learn how to deploy a web application to production. This course covers everything and happens to use Docker as a tool for certain aspects of it (Docker is used through out the course from beginning to end).

results.content:
Certain concepts are not very well explained - particularly docker-specific concepts.  Taking a little more time to explain the structure of a docker project's files would be hugely beneficial for a course about Docker.  

The approach seems to be "download the code I already wrote and let me go over what each line does," which makes the instruction feel hurried and difficult to keep up with.  It would be easier to follow and comprehend as a student if the files were written from the group up on screen in a step-by step manner, and the thought process explained.

I understand that this is not a course on shell scripting, Ruby on Rails, Flask, or Linux, so this approach is fine for non-docker code.  However, for at least files like Dockerfile, docker-compose.yml, and .dockerignore, it would be more beneficial to write them on-screen and take the time to explain each step and the rationale behind it.  Especially since there isn't really all that much content in these files, it would not make the videos substantially longer.  They would be much easier to comprehend though.

Finally, the classification of this course being an "all-levels" course is incredibly misleading.  As a professional software developer, I and finding the course more difficult to follow than other all-levels or beginner-level courses, because it assumes the user has a working knowledge of Linux, shell scripting, Python/Flask, Ruby/Rails, virtual machines, web servers, ssh, and many other technologies that a  novice would have no knowledge of.

I am not saying this course should be made more accessible to novices - DevOps its self is an advanced topic that many comp-sci graduates hardly know anything about.  However, in my opinion, this course should be listed as "intermediate" level at least, as a beginner would be completely lost almost right away, and likely request a refund.

results.content:
final rev 2.0:

# TLDR; this is an Awesome Course, totally worth it, Nick is great instructor and I will be refering back to this course content again as relevant to what I'm trying to do in real life. 
# -
# There is no question that Nick J Leveled Me Up in all the software he covered #
# -

This review is for "Docker for DevOps" by Nick Janetakis, as presented on udemy.com 

Nick is a native American-English speaker with a clear voice. He has the right mix of clarity + mild humor so you dont fall asleep. This is very important to me. 
  
  
Chapter 5+6 contains the Dockerfile + docker-compose.yaml - the true meat-n-potatoes of this course. That is what I paid for and what value I hoped to receive. Nick is apologetic at the length of these two sections, but to me that's what I wanted to see.
  
  

A significant chunk of this course was recorded in 2015, with overlay audio track commentary by Nick in the year 2020, and pop-up blue speech-bubbles to issue corrections and updates. Things from 2015 which are annoying and you didn't think you were paying for when you bought this course: 
     - virtualbox ver 5.x
     - detailed setup of debian linux + Digital Ocean droplets
     - detailed setup of sudo and ssh
     - whats different if you're using MacOS, Windows 7, Hyper-V, Docker Desktop or Windows WSL on Windows 10, or the real Docker on Linux (as God intended).

When I was 2-hours into the course, I resented the filler-content as either too basic or not relevant.
When I was 4-hours into the course, now I was excited because I learned things, and learned how to stitch them together into a usable-coherent whole.
When I was 5-hours into the course, I became sad because I knew the course was winding down.
I guess the only cure is to take more Nick J courses!

I knew enough "nginx" previously but to see Nick put it all together to containerize 2 webapps and use git and ssh and ssl certs and that makes me say "oh wow, this really is DevOps". 

However in aggregate, Nick will give very useful commentary or setup or comparison of other tools like vagrant, quick blips on Elastic, Logstash, Kibana, Swarm, kubernetes, et al. This is what you are paying for, for a guy with 20+ years of experience to tell you What's Up, rather than some fool who stumbled his way thru a CompTIA Cert 6 months ago, but ultimately has no real-world experience.

My wishlist is you would re-record the entire course using virtualbox 6.0 and the best linux, fedora or rhel. I love virtualbox and have been using it since the days of UnderRoos. virtualbox on a local machine you own will save you $1,200/year compared to doing it all on AWS and paying by the minute for every S3 request + hour of uptime on an EC2 instance.

Maybe scale back the Digital Ocean section in favor of a section on AWS, if you decide to produce a 2021 revision of the course.


# -
# There is no question that Nick J Leveled Me Up in all the software he covered #
# -


udemy.com Technical Issues during the course delivery: 
Firstly,
whatever CDN tricks udemy is using, they didn't mesh well with Firefox 76. In almost every chapter where there is downloadable content in form of a .pdf attachment it would cause the bottom video player controls to disappear, and my page lesson would abruptly skip to the next lecture. That was no bueno and I would have to hit Back or F5 to reload the page.

Secondly, 
the .pdf or .zip file course attachments either had the same filename 'original.zip' for EVERY chapter, or they would have unintelligible ${UUID}.pdf file names. You have to rename every file to keep them sorted.

Thirdly,  
the audio level is all UP and DOWN from your inserted comments & revisions from Future Nick. A little auto-gain / auto-level to keep it all at a consistent "7".

When I was 4-hours into the course, now I was excited because I learned things, and learned how to stitch them together into a usable-coherent whole.
When I was 5-hours into the course, I became sad because I knew the course was winding down.
I guess the only cure is to take more Nick J courses!

I knew enough "nginx" previously but to see Nick put it all together to containerize 2 webapps and use git and ssh and ssl certs and that makes me say "oh wow, this really is DevOps".

However in aggregate, Nick will give very useful commentary or setup or comparison of other tools like vagrant, quick blips on Elastic, Logstash, Kibana, Swarm, kubernetes, et al. This is what you are paying for, for a guy with 20+ years of experience to tell you What's Up, rather than some fool who stumbled his way thru a CompTIA Cert 6 months ago, but ultimately has no real-world experience.

My wishlist is you would re-record the entire course using virtualbox 6.0 and the best linux, fedora or rhel. I love virtualbox and have been using it since the days of UnderRoos. virtualbox on a local machine you own will save you $1,200/year compared to doing it all on AWS and paying by the minute for every S3 request + hour of uptime on an EC2 instance.

Maybe scale back the Digital Ocean section in favor of a section on AWS, if you decide to produce a 2021 revision of the course.

# -
# There is no question that Nick J Leveled Me Up in all the software he covered #
# -

udemy.com Technical Issues during the course delivery:
Firstly,
whatever CDN tricks udemy is using, they didn't mesh well with Firefox 76. In almost every chapter where there is downloadable content in form of a .pdf attachment it would cause the bottom video player controls to disappear, and my page lesson would abruptly skip to the next lecture. That was no bueno and I would have to hit Back or F5 to reload the page.

Secondly,
the .pdf or .zip file course attachments either had the same filename 'original.zip' for EVERY chapter, or they would have unintelligible ${UUID}.pdf file names. You have to rename every file to keep them sorted.

Thirdly,
the audio level is all UP and DOWN from your inserted comments & revisions from Future Nick. A little auto-gain / auto-level to keep it all at a consistent "7".

I got to know about this course via one of the reddit threads that I stumbled upon while researching about "best way to deploy flask application", and I bought this course immediately, after that. I have been going through this course while creating & deploying my own application which I am building for my company, parallelly.

This course has surpassed all my expectations and beyond.

You have no idea how helpful this course have been for people like me who are beginners in application development, wrapping my head around docker was very difficult but important as it is necessity for securely deploying an application these days.

There are few things I liked about this course:

1. Speech Rate: Its neither fast nor slow. It's perfect for people to hear and understand. I have taken many other courses, where instructors talks either very slow that you tend to fall asleep or too fast to catch up on.

Nonetheless, there have been few things that I couldn't understand at once like docker volumes but even for that Nick has responded my questions almost day I have asked on course forums, which are again very elaborative. 

3. Instant Practical Implementation.

4. Logically structured topics.

results.content:
The course has helped me tremendously in the understanding of docker, through the use of the flask app (did not watch the rails variant). After understanding yaml and the docker-compose files, I went on and applied docker to each of my portfolio sites and am completely sold.

It provides a bottom-up-approach, describing how to use certain linux tools such as systemd and sudo (helpful, but maybe not entirely necessary). 

Pro's:
- Beginner friendly
- When advanced items aren't completely covered, 3-5 minutes are spend on telling you what the options are and proposing of new learning areas
- Udemy support ( chat) is very active
- Backups, monitoring and management is (briefly) covered as well

Cons:
- More time on container focused operating systems wouldn't hurt
- Some of the jokes may fall flat >.<
- (personally, somewhat tech savy) I would decrease the pats about SSL, servers and domains in favor of more advanced docker topics 

All-in-all a very understandable and beginner friendly course to extend your docker knowledge.
